text: over the past year and a half Chinese
construction crews have been dumping
massive amounts of white sand in seven
spots in the South China Sea in
territory that China claims as its own
when the sand was in place those spots
were then covered in concrete and now
China says that at least some of its new
islands will soon be ready for use
why is this such a problem Beijing
insists it owns the territory inside the
so called nine-dash line a region
covering much of the South China Sea
it's ignored calls to halt construction
there and that's an issue for five
neighboring countries and territories
including Vietnam in the Philippines who
also claim part of the same body of
water
China argues the islands will be used
for peaceful purposes maritime search
and rescue work and biological research
but there's a real concern these islands
will become military bases to already
have runways there's a fear China will
declare an exclusion zone a bold attempt
to control this key maritime region
which could lead to military
confrontations this issue could affect
many more people than those in East Asia
more than half of global trade passes
through critical shipping lanes in the
South China Sea
so if tensions continue to increase in
these waters well it's the global
economy that could pay a heavy price
